title: Profiting From the Wine Experts
text:
Nick Jackson of Vintage Variation says fine-wine collectors “don’t need to have anything but the best.”

Text size

Pete Weber began collecting wine after observing prices surge for some of the California wines he enjoyed, like The Prisoner, a Napa Valley zinfandel blend that initially sold in the early 2000s for about $25 a bottle and today fetches closer to $50.

That was before the former tech executive began working with Charles Curtis, a private wine advisor, who helped him understand how much more difficult it is to sell a Napa blend on the secondary market than a desirable French Bordeaux or Burgundy—“wines that are truly collectible,” Weber says. “I learned quickly that what I was collecting wasn’t the right stuff.”

Curtis, who holds a prestigious Master of Wine designation from the Institute of Masters of Wine in London and is former head of wine for Christie’s in Asia and the Americas, is among a small group of highly educated and experienced private consultants who advise collectors of fine and rare wines.

For an annual fee that can run as high as $40,000 a year, Curtis—through his firm, WineAlpha—will guide collectors on the best wines to buy or sell to strengthen their collection’s value. He’ll also assist in selecting wines for a special celebration or an important dinner, or even take a client on a trip to Burgundy to visit favorite producers.

Curtis’ clients range from relative novices like Weber to longtime collectors with extensive cellars who may need guidance securing a loan against their holdings, authenticating the quality of their wines, or selling them.

Nick Jackson of Vintage Variation, also one of about 382 Masters of Wine worldwide, finds no two collectors are alike and that even the most experienced can improve the quality of their holdings, both for drinking and investment.

Collecting the ‘Right Stuff’ $40K High end of the annual fee Charles Curtis charges to advise collectors. 382 Number of Masters of Wine worldwide. $1,750 Amount Pete Weber paid for a case of Château Lynch-Bages 1986 at auction.

$2,350 Amount Curtis estimates the same lot would sell for at retail.

Seasoned collectors tend to make two mistakes: They are too conservative, buying the same wines over and over; or they are scattershot, purchasing bottles made by random producers from famous regions rather than focusing on the best producers, says Jackson, formerly the buyer for Sotheby’s retail wine business.

Fine-wine collectors “don’t need to have anything but the best,” he says. “There shouldn’t be any fat on the bone. It should all be really, really good stuff.”

It’s a strategy that pays off in the long run. In the Côte de Nuits—where the top wines in Burgundy are produced—a collector would be better off buying a wine from an excellent producer for $140 a bottle than one from a so-so producer for $120, Jackson says. The bottle from a fine winemaker selling for $140 today will gain in value over time, while the bottle from the lesser one likely won’t.

Jackson’s fees vary depending on a client’s needs. Typically, he charges a monthly retainer starting from about $600 for buying recommendations and perhaps placing a few bids at auction, to $3,000 a month to cover strategic planning across short-, medium-, and long-term purchases as well as for managing all the logistics of purchasing, including shipping and storage. “Either way, I work proactively, always looking out for buying or selling opportunities for my clients based on their tastes,” he says.

Both Jackson and Curtis were enmeshed in the auction world, where they gained valuable insider knowledge of how to strategize in a setting that can be intimidating to even the smartest of collectors. Jackson, for instance, advises submitting absentee bids as early as possible to gain priority.

Sabra Lewis—a former Radio City Rockette who found her way to wine and a career as a sommelier and private wine consultant—comes at wine collecting differently, believing the auction market limits collectors to a “tiny, tiny fraction of the wine world” focused only on top-tier, blue-chip producers.

“There are so many other types of wine that will be valuable, that already are valuable,” says Lewis, the former wine director at The Standard hotel at the High Line and former beverage director at L’Atelier de Joël Robuchon. Instead, she seeks bottles from excellent, often small-production growers discovered on the so-called gray market by enterprising dealers.

Most Champagne collectors, for instance, may not know Jacques Selosse—a pricey, highly desired Champagne, but one that rarely sells at auction. Those in the know will go to Italy, where a good amount is sold, and round up bottles to bring back legally to the U.S., where distribution is scarce, Lewis says. Selosse and other excellent wines produced with limited availability “will go up in value no matter what, as more people realize how great these wines are,” she says.

Working with Curtis, Weber has acquired collectible wines that he expects will appreciate. In early June, he bought about $50,000 worth from a Christie’s auction in New York, including 12 bottles of Château Lynch-Bages 1986 in their original wooden case for $1,750. Curtis estimates that the average retail price for this lot would have been about $2,350, although “sourcing at retail for older wines is very time-consuming and difficult, as it is very rare to find a full dozen in wood.”

Before working with Curtis, Weber learned from fine-wine retailers like Sherry-Lehmann, whom he still likes to buy from. But retailers are in the business of selling wine, he says, while Curtis, as a consultant, “helps me find wines at the right price.”
description: Fine-wine specialists guide collectors in building investment-worthy cellars that are a pleasure to drink, too
